abstract_summ: Correlation analysis revealed that ISI was positively correlated with total sleep time (TST) (r=0.435, p=0.026), and negatively correlated with deep sleep (r=−0.495, p=0.010); furthermore, patient SRQ scores were positively correlated with TST, sleep efficiency (SE) and REM (rapid eyes movement) sleep % (r=0.454 and 0.389, 0.512; p=0.020, 0.050 and 0.008, respectively).Similarly, depression symptoms (OR = 3.24, 95% CI: 1.19–8.79) were associated with poor sleep quality.The prevalence of poor sleep quality was 18.4% (95%CI: 16.6%–20.11%).An online questionnaire, including socio-demographics, the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), and the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS), was used to evaluate sleep disturbances and stress levels of healthcare workers.This study thus aimed to examine the prevalence of poor sleep quality and its demographic and correlates among frontline health professionals.
title_summ: A case-series examination.[Psychological status and sleep quality of nursing interns during the outbreak of COVID-19].The Evaluation of Sleep Disturbances for Chinese Frontline Medical Workers under the Outbreak of COVID-19Sleep quality and mood symptoms in conscripted frontline nurse in Wuhan, China during COVID-19 outbreak: A cross-sectional studyStress and sleep: a survey based on wearable sleep trackers among medical and nursing staff in Wuhan during the COVID-19 pandemicPoor-sleep is associated with slow recovery from lymphopenia and an increased need for ICU care in hospitalized patients with COVID-19: A retrospective cohort studyPrevalence and Demographic Correlates of Poor Sleep Quality Among Frontline Health Professionals in Liaoning Province, China During the COVID-19 OutbreakInsomnia and Stress of Physicians during COVID-19 OutbreakAnalysis of Psychological and Sleep Status and Exercise Rehabilitation of Front-Line Clinical Staff in the Fight Against COVID-19 in ChinaThe examination of sleep quality for frontline healthcare workers during the outbreak of COVID-19Sleep disturbances among medical workers during the outbreak of COVID-2019The Evaluation of Sleep Disturbances for Chinese Frontline Medical Workers under the Outbreak of COVID-19Is disruption of sleep quality a consequence of severe Covid-19 infection?
title_abstract_phrases: Correlation analysis revealed that ISI was positively correlated with total sleep time (TST) (r=0.435, p=0.026), and negatively correlated with deep sleep (r=−0.495, p=0.010); furthermore, patient SRQ scores were positively correlated with TST, sleep efficiency (SE) and REM (rapid eyes movement) sleep % (r=0.454 and 0.389, 0.512; p=0.020, 0.050 and 0.008, respectively).Insomnia and Stress of Physicians during COVID-19 OutbreakAbstract Background Healthcare workers are at high risk of developing sleep disorders during an outbreak.CONCLUSIONS: There are psychological symptoms and sleep symptoms in front-line medical staff who participate in the fight against COVID-19, and they affect each other.CONCLUSIONS: We observed that, during the outbreak of COVID-19, sleep disturbance was highly prevalent among paediatric healthcare workers, and sleep disturbance was independently associated with being an only child, exposure to COVID-19 patients and depression.Sleep quality, depression, and anxiety symptoms were measured using the Pittsburgh sleep quality index (PSQI), the Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-Item Scale (GAD-7) and the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), respectively.
